[GRAMMAR]: Awkward phrasing in "It is the foolishness of his kind to desire..."
Missing comma in "I had never possessed anything like _that_, and none of my friends..."
"gor he occupied no time" should be "for he occupied no time"

[STRUCTURE]: Long, meandering anecdotes with unclear connections
Overuse of specific book references without contextual explanation
[LOGIC]: Sudden shifts between different examples (dinner party, colonial squatter)
Confusing comparison between modern readers and the bushman
[CLARITY]: Ambiguous references to "that" and "this" without clear antecedents
[TRANSITION]: Abrupt transition from the dinner anecdote to the bushman example

[SYNTAX]: Run-on sentences (e.g., "It is the chief office...") disrupt readability.

[LOGIC]: Sudden shift from discussing the critic’s role to the French critic’s quote without clear transition.
[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transition from the "Cathedral" metaphor to the section on "subject" and the bookman’s catholicity.
[CLARITY]: Confusing phrasing in "the subject of the book does not enter into the matter" (unclear connection to prior ideas).
[TRANSITION]: Disjointed jump from the "Milton" example to the conclusion about needing a complete Milton and Masson’s Life.
